Pricing: Pros/cons of the most popular models for B2B SaaS
text:
Should you price a fixed fee per month? Per seat? The Max of usage during the month? Based on usage only (but what about predictability?) Implement a "fair billing" ? (What does that even mean?)

We crunched the pros/cons of the most popular models and decided to share our notes.

1/ Typeform: standard subscription model 2/ Snowflake: purely usage-based 3/ Customer.io: highest usage value recorded during the billing period 4/ Revolut Business: hybrid, mixing subscription, add-ons, and usage 5/ Retool: standard "per seat" pricing model 6/ Slack: fair "per seat" pricing (based on the active seats)

None of the models are one-size-fits-all, but hopefully it can support you in designing the right one for you.

Full post: https://www.getlago.com/blog/which-pricing-model-should-you-choose

Tell HN: Firefox Updates Too Frequently
text:
First a disclaimer. Firefox is a great browser, and my #1 choice.

However over the past 2-3 months I've noticed that the frequency of updates has increased. Most of these updates are of minimal impact, and in sem-ver language, are often patch releases.

While that is good and all, I, for the most part, don't want (or need) to update Firefox every time there's a bugfix that (most of the time) doesn't even apply to me. As an example, this morning I was prompted to install 106.0.1 (from my current 106.0) because of a single bugfix that affects users with AMD Zen 1 CPU's. I am on an M1 Mac. So yes, downloading a ~100MB update would be 1) unnecessary 2) wasteful, regardless of how little 100MB is in today's perspective (imagine how much that would be in 2003).

Yes, updates have gotten cheaper as compute and storage has increased over the years. But still, they all involve ~100MB each time, and in my opinion are somewhat abused in modern development cycles. Nobody except the Nightly crowd really cares about getting updates for each and every commit.

I acknowledge that this has become a problem with most software in general, but that is an issue to tackle another day. In the meantime, I would appreciate a setting to only be notified about Major/Security-Related releases. Suckless updates please.

Show HN: A search engine which only shows you upvoted content
text:
Hi guys,

Lately, I’ve noticed myself searching for things in Google and then typing Reddit (e.g. “opinion on Liz Truss reddit.”)

I tried to work out why I was doing this, initially thinking that I just wanted to enjoy the social aspect of the internet, but now I think I do it because, sometimes, I want to see results which have been filtered down by people, not by the Google search algorithm.

One of the many examples of where I think this can be useful is when searching for products or services. I know that if I Google “best laptop for gaming,” the results will be the products of large companies which have invested a lot of time and money getting onto the first page of Google, and won’t necessarily have the best products.

I built this as a way of searching through upvoted content across the internet (on multiple platforms), for when I want to search for something where a simple Google search won’t do.

It’s free-to-use, so feel free to try it out and I’d appreciate any feedback.

Thanks!
